header.title: Ageism in Comedy is No Joke
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Jerry Corley, writer for the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, 30-year comedian, screenwriter and founder of the Stand Up Comedy Clinic, talks about ageism in today's comedy industry. Ageism in comedy is real, but there are ways to work around it. . . http://standupcomedyclinic.com. http://facebook.com/jerrycorley. http://twitter.com/jokedoctor. http://instagram.com/jokedoctor. . Comedy Clinic Studio. 1213 W. Magnolia Blvd.. Burbank, CA 91506. (800) 883-3531
header.socioLingVar: Age - Over 65s,Nationality - German,Age - General,Nationality - General,Physical Identity - Physical (and Mental) Impairments,Gender - General,Age - Youngsters

commentThread.commentText:
Such an underrated video 

It really walls you through how things work out and you can equip that some of thinking to other problem in life.

I talk like this most of the time too. Most people get glazed eyes though.

The brand loyalty argument makes sense. But if you think about it, who are the media outlets that would be putting on the comedians? Are 18-34 year olds, or people in general brand loyalty to the media outlets in this day and age? Hardly. Anything you see on public transportation, even cable, will make it onto YouTube. I don't think media outlets capture much brand loyalty. If Carlin or game of thrones or sex and the coty switched networks, just about 100% of their watchers would move to the other media outlet imo. (Ok maybe 90%). If any brand loyalty was built, it would be for the comedian themselves. I'm not so sure media outlets would be so heavily invested into that, unless they signed some exclusivity agreement or major production agreement with that comedian for many years.
You also don't need people to pay you directly. Advertisements may want the 18-34 year old males. And the media network sells to those advertisers ad spots.

Thank you.

I find that this heuristic holds true:

Belief in the social justice "isms" generally correlates to ignorance, stupidity, and/or unwillingness to take on responsibility
George Carlin died in 1976? Damn!.... So all those movies he did 80's into the 2000's were him as a damn ghost! 😱👻 Lol. I have been thinking about getting into Stand-up,  but I'm 34....
2:24 Wow, you are old. Two lines on the dollar sign. ;) I keed! I keed! I'm old, too. lol.
Im addicted to your videos and cigarettes.

This is heavy. I thought that maybe I was in a bad situation for not being narrow with my pursuits. I can see so many good examples of how I've already been able to attract different traffic flow now. This is like diversifying your bonds in investing for a better chance at accumulated interest. I wasn't tapping into my different entertainment options as much as I could by only rapping.
Just getting started at 58. I'm up for a roast off!

As an aspiring comedian who is under 21, it's really hard for me to do comedy because there are about 3 under-21 clubs in the entire United States, 2 of them are in Texas and 1 of them is on fire at all times.

commentThread.commentText: Sorry, but you're all skewed on this. "In the demo" varies according to the programming. Some programs and channels have a very narrow demo while others are broader. It also depends on the level of sophistication in the humor. Is it "college-level" or is it for more "mature" audiences? Some acts work well on college campi while others are lounge acts in Las Vegas. Right now humor is very restricted at university venues. Jerry Seinfeld goes off his nut talking about this. Why perform in front of an audience that's primed to be offended rather than laugh? And of course all the good comedians are dead. Just like actors and musicians. Gone. All of them.

replies.commentText: We can only hope you're next lol

commentThread.commentText: This is such a good video and the title doesn't do it justice. I think everyone who wants to make it in comedy should watch it. I'm in my 20s and watched this purely out of curiosity, and I'm glad I did. It's about so much more than ageism and the advice of developing multiple skillsets and having many projects at the same time is spot on - kind of what Ari Shaffir recommends in his 4-hour recording that can be found on YouTube - bottom line, practice makes you better and doing comedy in more than one way prepares you for whatever opportunity might come your way in the future. Definitely going to take this advice. Thanks Jerry!
8:29 I'm going to go with positivity, but hearing comedians talking trash about other comedians they don't like is a guilty pleasure. :-)
Foster Brooks?

IMO, Carlin was a stand up philosopher. Like Mel Brooks, in his BEAUTIFUL "History of the World Part 1" 
Take me to funky town baby!
If you're old, simply do young comedy, if you're young, do old comedy. I'm middle aged so I'll just do your mom... Ohhhhh! Gotcha!

So what? This is the advantage of maturity. Young people have been so indoctrinated in victimization that they even create victim situations by looking for them. I don't care if they make it illegal for people over 40 to even do comedy, I will still do it and not complain. Life is not about fairness, it is about living YOUR life on YOUR terms... Why would Jerry even need to find someone to pick up his idea???? He has the money to produce anything he wants! BTW young comics today are totally unwatchable imo. T. Noah is the perfect example.
George Carlin and Jon Stewart are political comics. Political comedians have to be older in order for anyone to respect them. So the ageism issue is reversed in that regard.
